title: Beston Global Food Company's unorthodox arrangements
text:
Still in Adelaide, we have to admire the ingenuity of leading City of Churches corporate figure Roger Sexton.

The investment banker, ex-IOOF chair and now Beston Global Food Company chairman presides over an ASX-listed entity that's found a way to avoid disclosing its executive remuneration while paying a company owned by Sexton $2.4 million a year – a figure apparently calculated on a portfolio value that, as of Monday, must stand at more than four times its market capitalisation.

Former chairman of IOOF Roger Sexton. Penny Stephens

Did we mention Sexton is the South Australia and Northern Territory president of the governance-focused Australian Institute of Company Directors? Outstanding.

When Beston (the ASX-listed company) was set up, the idea was that it would operate as an asset management company. So it has an arrangement with Beston Pacific Asset Management, 71 per cent owned by Sexton and family, to act as its investment manager.

These days, though, Beston's main business is itself producing tonnes and tonnes of mozzarella. Which it does while not directly employing its CEO or CFO, who work for the management company instead.
description: We have to admire the ingenuity of Roger Sexton, these days the chairman of Beston Global Food Company.
